titlestmt.titleproper: Ivy City Oral History Project OHP.027
titlestmt.subtitle: An inventory of Ivy City Oral History Project at DC Public Library
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Lisa Moore.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-24 11:12:18 -0400.

change.item: Finding aid revised to be more evergreen.

did.unittitle: Ivy City Oral History Project Collection

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is housed in one box, 0.25 linear feet, and contains two series. The first series is organized alphabetically by last name of interviewee on the CD (some CDs contain multiple interviews, and group interviews), and contains 23 folders. The second series contains color 4"x6" photographs of some of the interviewees.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This collection is housed in one box and contains two series. The first series is organized alphabetically by last name of interviewee on the CD (some CDs contain multiple interviews, and group interviews), and contains 23 folders. The second series contains color 4"x6" photographs of some of the interviewees.
Series 1: Oral Histories
Series 2: Photographs

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ingrid Drake, CGAP (Certified Government Auditing Professional), is a program analyst with the Office of District of Columbia Auditor (OD.C.A). Previously, she was an investigator for the Washington-based nonprofit Project On Government Oversight (POGO); and was a writer, Pacifica Radio correspondent, and community educator living in Washington, D.C. In 2007 at the time of gift, she was a local D.C. journalist, writing for several outlets: D.C. North, East of the River, Hill Rag, D.C. Radio Co-op, www.D.C.Indymedia.org, WPFW 89.3 FM - Pacifica Radio, and Free Speech Radio News. Her contact information is: IngridNatasha@yahoo.com.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Basic archival processing procedures were applied to the collection when it was processed.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The information in the interviews was used in a book, African Americans and Gentrification in Washington, DC: Race, Class and Social Justice in the Nation's Capital, by Sabhiya Prince (New York: Routledge, 2014).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The information in the interviews was used in a book, "African Americans and Gentrification in Washington, D.C.: Race, Class and Social Justice in the Nation's Capital," by Sabhiya Prince (New York: Routledge, 2014).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
From 2005 and 2007, Ingrid Drake coordinated the Ivy City Oral History Project, in collaboration with the youth of Ivy City Achievers. She interviewed and supervised interviews with residents of the Ivy City neighborhood of Washington, D.C. The project was part of a larger initiative of Empower D.C., a grassroots nonprofit in D.C., called the Ivy City Neighborhood and Oral History Project, which began in 2004. The larger initiative arose from a plan to preserve Alexander Crummell School in the Ivy City neighborhood. Empower D.C. received funding for their efforts to document Ivy City's history from the Humanities Council of Washington, D.C. The resulting interviews were published in Ivy City Neighborhood and Oral History Project Booklet, an Empower D.C. project.
Additionally, Ingrid Drake produced a radio show for WPFW 89.3 FM of the final interviews. The interviewees discuss a history of black migration to Ivy City from the South, work histories, Ivy City memories, neighborhood churches, Sparrow's Beach (a private beach in Annapolis, Maryland for black vacationers during the Jim Crow Era of racial segregation, Alexander Crummell Elementary School, the 1968 D.C. uprising, neighborhood changes over time, drug use in the 1970s, Ivy City activism, gentrification, housing advocacy, Empower D.C., and the future of Ivy City.
The Ivy City Oral History Project collection is comprised of 23 audio CDs (21 CDs of interviews of 24 people, plus one CD of transcripts in the form of 16 Word [97-2003 version] documents of 19 interviews, and one CD of the final radio show), and 11 color 4"x6" photographs of 13 of the 24 interviewees. There are no transcripts for some interviewees. The radio show contains snippets of interviews interwoven with popular commercially-recorded music. Interviewed are 24 people: Aaron Aylor, Charles H. Brown, Alfred Coates, Theodore Coates, Clifford Coulson, Lula "Jackie" Council, Erica Crews, Okia Ferguson, Remetter Freeman, Dorothy "Nicey" Gary, Eleanor Grant, Sarah Parker Hunter, Marjorie Jones, Aujeneah Milner, Joel McPherson, Mohammed Mobaidin, Parisa Norouzi, Audrey Ray, Margaret Rice, Elaine Smith, Kenneth Tapscott, Romaine Thomas, Charlotte Tyner and Daisy Wroten.

did.unittitle: Series 1: Oral Histories
Ivy City Oral History Project, 2005-6

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Final radio show plus jewel case back text. CD-R, 700 MB, 80 min. Fuji. In plastic CD jewel case. Notes on cover include: A project of: Empower DC, the DC Radio Co-op, Crummell Alumni, DC Commission on Arts and the Humanities, and DC Humanities Council. Copyright 2006, My Company, Inc. All rights reserved. Thanks to all the people who agreed to be interviewed: Aaron Aylor, Charles Brown, Alfred and Theodore Coates, Colbert Coulson, Jackie Council, Erica Crews, Dorothy "Nicey" Gary, Eleanor Grant, Remetter Freeman, Okia Ferguson, Sarah Hunter, Marjorie Jones, Joel McPherson, Augeneah Milner, Parisa Norouzi, Audrey Ray, Margaret Rice, Elaine Smith, Kenneth Tapscott, Romaine Thomas, Charlotte Tyner, and Daisy Wroten. Without your help this would not be possible: Remetter Freeman, Bethesda Baptishs Church, Marcus Crews, Tony Crews, Sean Crews, Percy Williams, Antwan Williams, Ivan Blake, Aujeneah Milner, Greg Tyson, Ryme Katkhouda, Calenthia Dowdy, Catherine Benedict, Zainabu Dance, Dave Bosserman, Gail Taylor, Cathy Meals, Lauren Barthel, Ellen Chenoweth, Morgan Drake, Roshin Mathew, Schuyler Borton, Emily Rudicell, Lauren Boegen, WPFW Radio 89.3 FM, DC Indymedia - www.dc.indymedia.org. Produced by Ingrid Drake. ingridnatasha@yahoo.com
